author: dapplion
content: related point, why not apply correlated penalties at `EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR` instead of `EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR // 2`?

author: ralexstokes
content:
> Why is the balance of a slashed validator decreased immediately on slash_validator()? What invariant security property would be lost if the balance was only reduced on process_slashings()
why not? its easier to just do it in place, rather than defer

author: ralexstokes
content: after spot checking a few things, it doesn't seem like it would impact anything to batch this one balance change at epoch boundaries

author: ralexstokes
content: so if that's equal from an effects perspective, i'd elect to smooth as much work out as possible over the epoch, rather than batch everything every SLOTS_PER_EPOCH

author: ralexstokes
content:
> Why is a slashed validator not allowed to withdraw until EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR if correlated penalties (process_slashings) are applied on EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR // 2?
they probably could other than the fact that the current design has additional disincentives against slashing we may as well keep -- 1) opp cost of locked stake, 2) additional inactivity penalties

author: ralexstokes
content:
> why not apply correlated penalties at EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR instead of EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR // 2?
the `// 2` factor means you sample from the middle of the rolling window of all slashings, and use this value to tally the cumulative slashings

if you waited until the full length of the window, there could be stuff ahead of you that you should be penalized for that you otherwise would not

author: dapplion
content: In the spirit of correlating penalties of other network participants future actions should weight equally to past actions. If some event causes a mass slashing equally spaced over `EPOCHS_PER_SLASHINGS_VECTOR // 2`, the first affected will be penalized much less than that last
